full_text: What we wanna do in this video is prove that the measure of the angle formed by the intersection of a tangent and a chord is half the measure of the intercepted arc. So let's just make sense of what we're trying to prove, and then we will prove it. So we have two situations where we have an angle formed by a tangent and a chord. So there's one situation where it is acute, that's the scenario on the left. There's another situation where the angle formed between the chord and the tangent is obtuse. Now, what we wanna do in either of these cases is compare them to the measure of the intercepted arc. So in this situation right over here on the left, the intercepted arc is what I'm showing here in the yellow. So in this left scenario, what we want to show is that theta is equal to, we wanna show that it's half the measure of the intercepted arc. So we wanna show that it is half the measure of arc BC. That's what we wanna show in this scenario. In this scenario, we wanna show that theta is equal to half the measure, and here we're gonna be thinking about the major arc. So this is the intercepted arc in this scenario. So we wanna go all the way around, and for major arcs, we use three letters to show that we're going the long way around. So this is the measure of arc, we could call this BEC. B-E-C. So let's get to it. So in this left scenario, what I'm gonna do is draw some radii. So this over here and this over here, this is a circle, so the radius is constant. So we know that this length is equivalent to that length. We also have proved in other videos, or you might know, that the angle between a radius and a tangent is going to be 90 degrees. So that right over there is 90 degrees, or another way you could think about it is this would also be 90 degrees. Well, if we know that, if we know that this angle is 90 degrees, then what is the measure of this angle right over here? Well, that angle plus theta has to be equal to 90 degrees, so this is going to be 90 minus theta. Well, what we're dealing with here is an isosceles triangle, so if this angle is 90 minus theta, then this angle right over here, because these two sides are congruent, so this is also going to be 90 minus theta. So my question is, what is this angle going to be? And this angle's measure is the same as the measure of arc BC. So it's going to be the angles in a triangle add up to 180, so this is going to be, let me just color another color right over here, so it's going to be 180 minus this, minus 90 minus theta, minus 90 minus theta. That's the measure of this angle. And so this is going to be equal to, if I just distribute the negatives and simplify, this is 180 minus negative 90, negative 90, so minus 180. And then if I multiply that times theta, it's plus theta plus another theta, so plus two theta. And so those cancel out, so we're just left with the two theta.
